I used to believe there was intrinsic value in crypto in that it was a good way to conduct secure transactions across borders and countries and things, but in reality, it's not all that secure, you can figure out who's doing what transactions by monitoring internet traffic, we can't figure out what the exact price of any particular cryptocurrency should be, meaning its not fundamentally all that different than fiats, fiats are at least tied to the governments that issue them, and most governments on Earth, even the least stable ones, are certainly more stable than the average startup

What people fail to understand is most transactions done through cash are 100x more secure than trading with crypto, it's way more untraceable, otherwise it wouldn't be king for drug deals, you could theoretically send someone to China with a flash drive or some code written on a vinyl or piece of paper that either has the crypto itself on it or a code needed to complete the transaction, but that's maybe the only way it would make things actually private since any and all transactions through the internet and global network are not private at all.

threads.sub: The Next Trade: Long Duration Bonds
threads.com:
Hear me out, TLT (+20yr t-bonds) had its worst year on record, and is one of the worst performing assets this year (crypto and unprofitable tech aside). It was so bad actually, that it passed the 3-sigma line from the regression line. Just so you understand, 2-sigma is already an outlier. So long bonds are critically oversold.

But why should they go up you ask (because things can remain oversold for long). There are two reasons. First, US inflation is coming down, and it's are coming down with a lag. The coming data from housing suggests that one of the major components of the CPI - owner's equivalent rent - is going to significantly fall in the coming reports. So inflation is a 2022 story and will likely die out going into 2023 H2.

Second, if you aren't blind, then you know that the US economy is headed for a recession next year. How bad that would be in GDP and earnings terms is hard to say, but the bond market is SCREAMING recession. A recession means that the FED will have more room to halt its rate hikes and even maybe pivot completely. Falling short-term rates are extremely bullish for long duration bonds.

The only way that this trade does not work is if inflation suprises to the upside and the terminal FED rate will be higher than what is currently priced in - about 5%. If you think that this will play out, then don't buy bonds. But if anything else happens, this trade will be THE trade of 2023.
How to play this trade:
First possibility is to buying the spot TLT, which is very easy and simple. Since I don't think this is a late trade by any measure, buying it outright is a sensible thing to do.
Second, if you don't want to tie up too much capital to this, VIXTLT is still high so doing some call bull spreads is a very good idea. You will gain from selling that further OTM call. I will take at least 90 DTE.
Third, if you think you're bit late, sell puts/bull spreads. Less upside but still positive delta.

Good luck and see ya in 2023 H2 when TLT is $140.

threads.com:
Here’s why chainlink will revolutionize banking

Banks are constantly moving money to each other. This is a hard problem. Establishing trust and security is not easy

I’ll start with a simple example and gradually increase complexity

Assume Bob and Alice bank at Wells Fargo, and Bob wants to send Alice $10. Simple. Wells Fargo decreases Bob’s balance by $10 and increases Alice’s by $10

Now what if Bob wants to send money to Charlie who banks with Citi. Well now Wells Fargo needs to communicate with Citi in some way. Wells Fargo does this by establishing an account with Citi. They decrease $10 from Bob, send $10 to their account to Citi, and then request Citi increase Charlie’s balance by $10.

Here are some of the pitfalls. What if Bob wanted to send $100 million? Now Wells Fargo opens themselves up to massive loss if Citi fails. In addition, transaction costs will add up.

Now think about how many banks there are. There are around 25,000 banks globally. When a bank needs to send money to another bank, they need to establish a connection. So there can be potentially 25000 * 24999 different accounts simply for bank to bank transfers. Coupled with providing liquidity this simply isn’t scalable

Current day solution is to use a clearing house. Every bank will open an account with them. The clearing house will ensure money is properly debited and credited across banks while reducing transaction fees. Think of them as performing splitwise operation at the end of the day but on a massive scale.

The big problem here is that not all banks connect to a unified clearing house. It’s distributed and it can be tough to send money to an unaffiliated bank. In addition, security and trust are entrusted to the clearing house

CCIP will eliminate the need of clearing houses. Trust is decentralized and security is publicly auditable. The ease of connecting to the network will allow even the most meager of credit unions to participate relatively quick.

>>52599110
>Why?
Population increase + automation + cost cutting = more demand, less supply
-There are more working adults than ever, year on year.
-More of all jobs, even physically demanding ones, can be done with help from technology (e.g. an Amazon warehouse, used to be that people would be responsible for all the tracking and work orders, now it's all tech and all humans do is the packing/driving). So less roles available.
-Nowadays most companies run with the expectation they'll be understaffed to save money on wages, and make their other workers take on more responsibilities to compensate. They can demand the best candidates and that everyone goes above and beyond.

So people are working harder than ever for less reward, and employers can get away with it because there are so few roles available. Not a great time to be starting out in the job market, or in it at all really.

There are two things you say here

Yes, but keep in mind we are simply talking about investing either into Pile A (stocks) or Pile B (RE) this all depends on the current real estate boom continuing as it has. Real estate has performed well recently but that is no excuse to discount the entire history of the market vis a vis stocks (which return an average of 10% historically). So the money you bank in equity is simply a reflection of an investment in that market.

Now that that’s out of the way (And I have to point it out because everyone makes the argument that “building equity” is a separate notion, somehow divorced from the basic calculus of investment)

> “My choice (Pile B) has outperformed stocks to such an outrageous degree, how is that possible”

Aside from the fact that there has been an outrageous RE boom, you have essentially held a margined position on your home. You could have gone underwater just as easily in a proper crash, so don’t act like that 4x multiplier you got couldn’t be done with an index fund held on margin - its the exact same thing, and again RE is historically trumped by investment in stocks full stop, and no amount of rhetoric can change that one investment is simply better than the other

That said, there are plenty of opportunities in RE, plenty of market disparities and areas where if you had to live there, renting might somehow see far more or less favorable. Additionally if you have a little vinegar in you, you can make a killing flipping properties or cash flowing them, even just getting lucky in a hot marker like Denver or austin can put you into 20% yearly ROI territory. Anons, there has been something that I have been wondering about for quite a while...first, I will present things as I see them and then I will posit my theory on things(market cycles).
First, all crypto is currently connected. These connections happen through liquidity pools. We create pairs, which then interact with other pairs that have one of the tokens in them, and thus creates a chain of price action when one in the pair moves. The actual movements here are extremely complicated and you would need vast amounts of data to even have an inkling of how much price movement of X effects Y. My 2nd point here is liquidity itself. If you have a high price of a token and you want to keep the price high, you either buy pressure to counteract sells, or you need a deep as fuck pool of liquidity in that sells dont move the price much at all. Having too much liquidity is an issue though, especially if you have a low price and want that price to go higher, in this example having a lot of liquidity protects the price from moving up(due to the nature of how our liquidity pools operate). This sort of thing can controlled via incentives, too much liquidity, kill incentives and people will leave, too little and add incentives, people will come. Now my theory: these liquidity incentives are being controlled by people trying to artificially move the market one way or the other. You want the price to crab, add a fuckton of liquidity, want a moon? Remove liquidity and shill the fuck out of things, while placing some small buys to move the price to generate FOMO. Want a crash, remove liquidity and add FUD.

but honestly, this chain seems like the real deal. The chain is EVM/cosmos hybrid which is really nice for various reasons. the entire basis for the chain is also to integrate various tools into the chain and treat them as public utilities. I will give you one example of this, there is a built in AMM into the chain, these contracts are not available via UI, instead they are contract only assets. This allows for protocols to build their own UI on top and add any additional features they would like to differentiate themselves from other offerings. The underlying contract has 0 fees involved as it is a public utility, however the DEX that builds can choose to add their own fee (they have other features to charge for). There is also the benefit that any contract that is created reserves a portion of the gas used on the contract and pays the contract creator for the contracts use. Its a really innovative way to attract protocols that have razor thin margins to migrate over to gain the gas fee sharing. There are lots of other ideas similar to these that are based on the concept of features being public utilities.
